This is GREAT !! But there's something else I'd like to see. I'm in different fields now so I topped waiting for it long ago, but it could still happen, maybe already has. Oliver Heaviside(1857-1925), a more or less self taught Victorian era physicist believed in modeling and inventing mathematical operations based on the actual physics of the thing being investigated So, for example, he used divergent series to model electromagnetic waves in cables, accounting for their reflections and loss of energy.

Less well known is that Oliver cobbled together his own way of doing Vector calculus and spoke of it in passing but I was never quite able to grasp his way of doing it and his notation was non-standard as well. But it is clear from his writings that he saw exact analogies between physical phenomena, for example the inside of a tornado, and the vector calculus models of it. If only he had gone into more detail ! There is a fairly recent bio of him, within the last 20 years or so which I've never read, maybe they mention it, I don't know.

I worked on it in the mid 1970's after getting copies of microfilms of his notebooks from the British Institution of Electrical Engineers while I was a student in the EE program at Univ. of Rhode Island. Eventually I donated the films and my own notebooks to the Brown Univ. Dept. of Electrical Engineering where they no doubt were lost for all time.

When a 3D line is a vertical line passing through the center of view (COV), it is perpendicular to the horizon line. When a 3D line’s intercept with the horizon is to the right of the “y axis” , it forms an angle which is 90 degrees + “a” degrees, where “a” gets larger as the 3D line’s intercept moves further to the right along the x axis. When the 3D line’s intercept with the horizon is to the left of the y axis, it forms an angle which is 90 degrees - “b” degrees, where “b” gets larger as the line moves further to the left on the x axis.

I’m confident there’s a beautiful bit of maths hiding in here somewhere, and probably a really cool function to determine what angle any given 3D line should make with the horizon given where it intersects the horizon with respect to the center of view and the field of view of the viewer. Stephen Hicks,
The reason everything was difficult was the way in which subjects were taught using the 19th century brick & mortar educational model. . A one hour lecture in a 30 person classroom combined with lesson goals provided by the decision makers, restricted the learning process to rote memory. The students who survived the process and went on to become future teachers were the students who able to quickly memorize the subject matter better than the rest of the class.


One flaw in the process is, memorizing a lecture does not necessarily mean that it is thoroughly understood. If the solution of a math problem requires 17 steps to be completely defined and only 9 of the steps are presented in the lecture, the "solution" will not make complete sense. In order to survive the course, the incomplete "solution" is simply memorized whether on not it is actually understood. The student repeats the incomplete solution on the test, receives an A grade and becomes the next teacher. When they teach their students, their lecture is presented in the same way. In other words, those with great memories survive the process but may not understand the subject much better than those who did not survive.


Online learning and particularly YouTube University can and has changed that. Now a lecture no longer has the time restrictions that had to be implemented with the 19th century brick & mortar educational model. If a YouTube lecture leaves steps out of a solution or more background information is required, the student can review the problem from additional sources and then replay the lecture. The lecture can be replayed and reviewed as many times as necessary to completely understand the problem. This was not possible in 1971.

During the 1860s, J C Maxwell set out 20 tedious partial differential equations summarizing all that had been learned about electric charge and magnetism since Coulomb. Vector calculus, with its curl and divergence operators, had yet to be invented (by Willard Gibbs at Yale, and by Oliver Heaviside in the UK). Once it was understood that electric charge and magnetism were vector fields, and that the curl, divergence and gradient of those vector fields was a thing, Maxwell's 20 equations reduced to 4 equations saying the following (assuming Planck units and a vacuum, so that current density J = charge density rho = 0):
* The divergence of each vector field is zero;
* The curl of each vector field = the gradient of the other vector field, except for one minus sign that arises because unlike positive and negative charge, magnetic north and south are never separate entities; as far as we know, magnetic monopoles do not exist.
Using the notation of differential forms (as explained in Penrose's Road to Reality), Maxwell's equations reduce even further to dF = d*F = 0.

One interesting quirk of the cross product (and therefore, of the curl of a vector field, ∇xF⃗), is that it actually is definable in any number of dimensions, 2 and up, but only in 3D is it a vector (actually, a "pseudovector," because it fails to invert under spatial inversion).
In n dimensions, it is a tensor (pseudo tensor, when n is odd) of rank n–2.
It can also be cast instead, as a tensor of rank 2, regardless of n; similar to a rotation tensor.

This only briefly touches on Maxwell, and it is not the real Maxwell, since it has only 4 equations. It is the shameful Heaviside simplification. The true set of Maxwell's Equations is a group of 20 'quaternions', each of which involves complex numbers, as they must for accuracy. In the Heaviside simplification, there are no complex numbers, which guarantees that it is only partially accurate, at best... kind of a "fake news" version of the truth, which has persisted for many decades, to the point that many people are not even aware that it is a lie.

Allow me to correct you.

The divergence of the electric field due to point charges is not +1/-1 at a source/sink as you claimed, but instead is positive infinity/negative infinity at a positive/negative charge. The divergence is zero everywhere else.

True proper curl is not just a thing in three-dimension. A curl is defined for each (finite) dimension. And the true proper curl does not assign a vector to each point in space. It instead assigns a bivector to each point in space. It just happens that bivectors in 3D space has a bijective correspondence to 3D vectors.

I've been thinking about this all day and finally sat down tonight to try to work parts of it out. I came up with this: let function f(z) be a complex function where z = a + bi. To take the derivative of this in the "x" dimension (using the plotting system), we would take df(z)/da. Using the chain rule this works out to be df(z)/dz * dz/da. Since z = a+bi, this is equal to df(z)/dz * d(a+bi)/da. Since d(a+bi)/da = 1, this means that df(z)/da = df(z)/dz, which I think is quite an insight. You can do a similar thing with respect to b except an i ends up in there. Someone please correct me if I am wrong.

Edit: I think I figured it out. If you have a vector field where the x component is the derivative with respect to a of a complex function, and the y component is the derivative with respect to b, this means the curl and divergence will always be 0. Using my above formulas, if we call the function f(z), we get our vector field as <df(z)/da, df(z)/db> = <df(z)/dz, -i*df(z)/dz>. Taking the divergence of this we get d^2(f)/dz^2 + (-i)^2*d^2(f)/dz^2 = 0. Curl is much easier to show and does not require the above insight. Anyway, I hope 3blue1brown goes more in depth as to why this occurs in the next video.

Edit: Actually I'm pretty sure I'm missing something major here

Around the turn of the century I was working on my bachelors in Electrical Engineering. Even though I had high grades for most of the subjects, especially the hard math and physics subjects, I decided to switch to Computer Sciences after four years, without a degree. The main culprit was electromagnetic wave theory. I had always relied on being able to find an intuitive understanding of the subject matter to pass my exams, and that method started to fail when the full force of Maxwell's equations hit. No matter how hard I studied, I just didn't 'get' how the behaviour emerged from the equations, even though I understood them separately. Your explanation has given me a glimpse of that understanding for the first time. Thank you for that. I'm positive this will help students who are struggling with these subjects in the same way I was.

Secondly, I greatly appreciate your explanation of the matter of sponsoring, and I think that you hit the nail right on the head. Conflicting interests are hard to balance in the long run despite best intentions, and direct support can avoid them. Avoidance still relies on the assumption that changes in integral of the [value per person]-[people reached] function will cause equivalent changes in direct support over time, but this assumption is probably true. At least for that part of the function you wish to reside in. That, of course, assumes that the increase in direct support is a motivation for you, and not only maximizing that area. But I would be very suspicious if you would claim otherwise ;)

Long story short, I will become a patron of your channel as soon as I manage to find back my credit card :)

I feel deeply compelled to mention the existence of geometric algebra (also known as Clifford algebra, though this is somewhat obfuscatory). As an algebra that unifies vector spaces of arbitrary dimension with complex number algebras, automatically and effortlessly generating the appropriate one for each vector space, and including the merger of the dot and cross product operations (properly generalizing the latter to higher dimensions with rotary bivectors), geometric algebra might be very handy in cleanly extending what's coming to dimensions higher than two.

It even generalizes to hyperbolic metrics like space-time. A research project I did on special relativity a few months ago is actually the reason I found out about this; namely, because it can express Maxwell's four equations as a single (very compact) differential equation in space-time (without the use of matrices), and correctly describes EM fields as space-time rotors in 6 bivector planes (three space-space planes and three space-time planes; with the implicit quadvector and the ever-present scalar, these are biquaternions, IIRC).

I'm actually seriously obsessed with this algebra now ... I mean, how can't I be obsessed with something that can describe the radial vector of spherical coordinates as a complex exponential nested inside of and twisting the plane of another complex exponential!

I study aerospace engineering in uni, and we actually wrote a MATLAB code for an incompressible flow course that could calculate the lift of a NACA airfoil using the panel method. The essence of panel method was the implementation of many mass sources and vortex sources in a steady, horizontal 2D flow field, slightly different from the modeling method discussed in this video. In our case, mass sources modeled the physical boundary and shape of the airfoil, while vortex sources introduced varying fluid velocities on the top and bottom surfaces. Their effects could then be summed together to get fluid velocity vectors at all points around the airfoil, which could then be used to find lift.

A fun fact is that the nabla symbol was introduced by Hamilton who invented quaternions in early 1800's, with definition being i∂_x + j∂_y + k∂_z.  It's a quaternionic first derivative operator (in fact, a Dirac operator).  As it works on vector fields with quaternion product, it produces divergence in the real part and curl in the imaginary part.

You did mention it in your video but I feel obligated to reiterate: dynamicists do not in general use div/curl to analyze phase space. As mentioned in the video, we analyze the Jacobian, specifically the eigenvalues -- this comes from the Hartman-Grobman theorem. Since the divergence of a function is the trace of the Jacobian, and the trace of a matrix is the sum of the eigenvales, the sign of the divergence will be negative at point attractors and positive at point repellors. However, it obscures some of the information; you may have one smaller positive and one larger negative eigenvalue, which will give a negative divergence, but the point will be a saddle point and not an attractor. The curl is even less helpful, as it only really exists in on orientable 3-dimensional Reimannian manifolds, which limits its use to mostly just physical systems. It's great to see dynamics get a mention, but I don't want to see it get misrepresented.

For those who stopped to ponder the differential equations: There is a problem with the DE for the fox. If delta*rabbit = gamma, then the fox population stays constant no matter how many foxes there are. If we let the number of foxes approach infinity, intuition tells us that the fox population would decrease rapidly due to starvation (since the amount of rabbits is finite), and yet the model predicts a constant fox population. A more accurate model would be d(fox)/dt=delta*rabbit-gamma*fox.

Back in the mid ‘80s, during my electronics degree, I struggled with complex vector calculus. Math was not my strong suit. One lecture in telecommunications, the lecturer walked into the room, turned his back on the class, said barely a word and started writing on the board. At the end of the lecture he said “and those are Maxwell’s equations” and packed up.

If I’d known the importance of what he was doing to start with, or had felt able to follow or even ask questions, that could have been the best lecture of my academic career. But that I’d been completely lost through such an important moment was the straw that broke the camel’s back, and I dropped out, only to complete a lesser qualification.

I so regretted that, and it’s wonderful finally to have the sense that I may at last be able to grasp this. Grad, Div and Curl almost beat me. And I’ve avoided heavy calculus ever since. If only I had a time machine...
